Most 2-strokes do not have a dedicated oil lubricating system (although some use auto-lube systems). So you mix the oil with the fuel and then use the fact that the crankcase pressurises the oil/fuel mixture to provide lubrication (in small ones, that is).

Completely depends on the rest of the exhaust system. It will definitely sound different but the type and especially the condition of the rest of the exhaust tract is the main factor. Some cars will be very loud, some won't and most will be in between.
Is yours fuel injected or not? Many cars will have a fit if the cat is removed and the CEL will come on straight away. But depends on how new/old/complex the engine management system actually is.
The cat converter is there to convert (hence the name) harmful things like nitrogen oxides into less harmful species. They also can get rid of CO and unburnt fuel to some extent.
The device needs to reach a high temperature to function correctly. In most applications, by the time it is hot enough to work the engine has stopped producing most of what the cat was designed to get rid of. Modern engines usually place the cat as close to the engine as possible so that it heats up quickly.
And finally, over time the cat will be 'poisoned' - it will lose effectiveness until it does nothing at all. Some engine management systems will detect this and some won't.
Exactly. When you buy a cat-back system, the maker assumes the cat remains in the same place. So you just bolt it straight on. Still a waste of time, though for most vehicles.
He's just thankful it's not him.

WRITING.TITLE: Having a problem starting the latest NMM. Files are missing and I don't like the look of the .exe file it suggests I download and run to fix it
WRITING.TEXT:

.NET framework version 4.5.2 missing. Do you want to install now?

dotnetsocial.cloudapp.net
and wants me to download and install some file called:
NDP462-KB3151802-Web.exe
What the fuck is that? I've never had to do that with NMM before. Should I trust this? Why isn't the NMM install working like it always did before?
